title: Virtual Conversation: Who's Afraid of Contemporary Art?
hero_caption: Jay DeFeo (Mary Joan DeFeo). The Annunciation (detail),1957/59. Gift of Lannan Foundation. © 2018 The Jay DeFeo Foundation / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York.
short_description: Whether you love contemporary art, or don't know where to begin, this program, led by Gabriela Trinidad-Pérez and Lillian Young, will deepen your appreciation for some of the most dynamic and challenging artworks in the museum collection.
list_description: Whether you love contemporary art or don't know where to begin, this program will deepen your appreciation for some of the most dynamic—and challenging—artworks in the museum collection.
description:
Whether you love contemporary art, or don't know where to begin, this program, led by Gabriela Trinidad-Pérez and Lillian Young, will deepen your appreciation for some of the most dynamic and challenging artworks in the museum collection.

Gabriela Trinidad-Pérez is a Caribbean arts professional, artist, and student enrolled in the dual degree program in Modern and Contemporary Art History and Arts Administration and Policy at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. She earned a BA in sociology and art history from the University of Puerto Rico. Her academic practice engages an interdisciplinary approach in the sectors of queer and gender theory, visual culture, cultural identity, and contemporary art like photography and film. Through her work as a cultural administrator and educator, she focuses on contemporary artistic connections between the United States and Puerto Rico, while also working in spaces that foster, promote and cater to queer, BIPOC, Latinx, and Caribbean communities.

Previously, Gabriela has worked for the academic magazine Visión Doble, the production company Como Imágenes, and the research center CRiiAS. Currently, she is a teaching assistant in the Art History and Academic SPINE departments at SAIC, and a graduate peer advisor for students seeking professional development. This summer she will be an intern in the Art Institute's Department of Learning and Public Engagement. During her free time, Gabriela holds an artistic practice centered in mosaic, hoping to bridge the gaps between craft and contemporary art.

Lillian Young is a summer intern in the Art Institute's Department of Learning and Public Engagement. She is a historical artist, focused on under-represented moments and people in African American history, and has taught in various galleries, classrooms, and online settings. Lillian’s teachings focus on helping guide others to interpreting art in their own way and create a better understanding of what art can be. She attended Texas Christian University where she received her BFA in studio art with an emphasis in art education. Currently Lillian is working on her MFA in studio art with a certification in museum studies at Michigan State University.

We recommend using a laptop or desktop computer and downloading the latest version of Zoom to enjoy this program.

If you have any questions about virtual programming, please reach out to museum-programs@artic.edu.

For questions related to accessibility accommodations, please email access@artic.edu.
